[Question]
i m f currently on a work trip with a few of my coworkers most of whom i ve known for year but haven t seen in person since covid started i m decently close with one person in particular and the rest i just have a normal professional relationship with last night everyone went out to celebrate a big milestone during the trip and had a great time i wa definitely pretty drunk by the end of the night and getting home is a little hazy but i woke up with good memory of the night before and wasn t concerned that anything had happened anyways no one had texted me this morning and i wasn t sure what the plan for the day wa so i reached out to the coworker i m closer with and asked what she wa up to she said she wa going to breakfast with another person on the trip and that i could come which i agreed to but then she texted and said they were actually leaving right now for breakfast and that we could meet up later this seemed odd to me since we re all in the same hotel and i could have been ready to head out whenever but it felt like she didn t want me to come i think i m reading into it a bit too much but now i m freaking out worried that i did something wrong last night and that s the reason i m not being invited along today i don t really have a track record of doing thing out of character while drunk though so i m just really confused and anxious tldr got drunk with coworkers who i haven t seen in a while and now it feel like no one want to hang out with me

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how confusing and anxiety-inducing this situation is for you. It's natural to feel concerned when you wake up and realize that something might have happened the night before, especially if you've had a lot to drink. However, it's important to remember that people can have different interpretations of what constitutes "having a good time" and it's possible that your coworkers simply wanted to start their day without you.

You mentioned that you have a normal professional relationship with most of your coworkers, so it's unlikely that anything you did during the celebration would have caused them to exclude you from their plans. It's also worth considering that they might have had other reasons for leaving earlier than planned, such as personal commitments or other plans.

To alleviate your anxiety, try focusing on the things you can control in this situation. You can reach out to the coworker you're closer to and express your confusion about why they didn't invite you to breakfast. However, it's important to approach the conversation with an open mind and avoid jumping to conclusions. You might find that there was a misunderstanding or miscommunication that can be easily resolved.

In the meantime, try to engage in activities that make you feel good and help you relax. This could include going for a walk, practicing deep breathing exercises, or engaging in a hobby you enjoy. Remember, it's normal to feel a little down or anxious after a night of heavy drinking, but these feelings should pass with time.

If you continue to feel overwhelmed by these emotions, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide you with additional guidance and support. They can help you explore any underlying issues that may be contributing to your anxiety and develop coping strategies tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

im seriously so stuck i developed a horrible case of health anxiety and constantly think something is wrong with my brain or heart i ve been to the er twice now with everything coming back normal i feel bed ridden most day if im up and moving around for too long i feel extremely dizzy due to my tension headache i have high blood pressure and am on medication but i constantly think it s hurting my heart im only year old and i shouldn t be this concerned about my health i m so over feeling this way and every day get worse and worse i feel like i can t do anything but lay down i get sharp pain along my chest due to costochondritis and im always thinking it s the end my breathing is always fine and my heart never beat super rapidly so that make me feel better but the dizziness is unbearable i tried antidepressant and all they did wa make my anxiety worse and my heart beat abnormally fast anytime i stood up my doctor took me off of them and is more focused on my blood pressure im so scared of dying and i m so sick of feeling like this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It's important to remember that you're not alone in feeling this way, and there are steps you can take to manage your health anxiety and improve your overall well-being.

Firstly, it might be helpful to explore the root cause of your health anxiety. While I'm not a mental health expert, I can offer some general suggestions. Consider keeping a journal to track your thoughts and feelings throughout the day. This can help you identify any patterns or triggers that contribute to your anxiety. Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation may help alleviate some of the dizziness and overall discomfort you're experiencing.

Regarding your medication, it's crucial to communicate openly with your doctor about your concerns. They may be able to adjust your dosage or suggest alternative treatments that could address both your high blood pressure and anxiety. Remember, it's essential to work closely with a healthcare professional who can provide personalized guidance based on your specific situation.

While it's understandable that you're feeling scared and concerned about your health, it's important to focus on building a support system around you. Surround yourself with understanding friends or family members who can offer emotional support during this challenging time. Additionally, consider seeking out online communities or support groups where you can connect with others who may be experiencing similar health anxiety symptoms.

Lastly, if your symptoms persist or worsen, it's important to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide you with the appropriate care and guidance. They can help you develop coping strategies tailored to your needs and work towards managing your health anxiety effectively.

Remember, you deserve to feel better and live a fulfilling life. Don't hesitate to seek the help and support you need to overcome this challenging period.

i m not sure if i have anxiety or adhd or im just introverted and procrastinating lol i started biting my nail since i wa a kid i tried hard to get rid of this habit but it not something i can control i put on nail polish usually but once it fall ill start biting them or fixing them with nail clipper a little bit of unsmoothness on my nail will bother me a lot and ill just sit there and keep fixing it for hour straight instead of doing any work literally every 0 min i would find somewhere bothering me on my nail i also overthink a lot it might be influenced by my mom who kept telling me that others might think negatively about me bc of any barely noticeable detail about what i do how i look so now i will just replay some scenario in my head hundred of time feel bad about myself and had to take deep breath say to myself it ok out loud or make some sudden noise to make my mind jump out of that vicious loop recently i feel that my attention span is getting even shorter i will sit down for work and get distracted after min and start watching youtube video for hour i notice myself doing that and i would think maybe i should go back to work but the other part of my mind is like numb and fail to take any action to the point that im only able to focus for a long time under pressure like a day before meeting or exam idk if it is just bad work ethic procrastination introversion or i should get a check up for anxiety adhd like i heard other ppl relate to me on point amp so idk if it just some common problem that i can just work it out either way can anyone give me any advice on whether to get a diagnosis or smth i could do on my own to mitigate these behavior thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand that you're feeling uncertain about whether you have anxiety, ADHD, or if it's just your introverted nature and procrastination. It's important to remember that everyone's experiences are unique, and it might be helpful to explore these symptoms further.

To start, let's focus on your nail biting habit. While it's understandable that you've tried to get rid of it, it seems like something you can't fully control. Instead of trying to completely eliminate the habit, you could try finding alternative ways to cope with stress or boredom. For example, you could try keeping your hands busy with activities like knitting, painting, or playing an instrument. Additionally, you mentioned that putting on nail polish usually helps, so perhaps you could try incorporating that into your routine as a reminder to stop biting.

Regarding your attention span, it's common for individuals to struggle with staying focused, especially when they're feeling overwhelmed or distracted. One technique you could try is breaking down your tasks into smaller, manageable chunks. By focusing on one task at a time, you may find it easier to maintain your attention and make progress. Additionally, creating a structured schedule and setting specific goals for yourself can help you stay motivated and on track.

You mentioned that you overthink a lot and tend to replay scenarios in your head, which can lead to feelings of self-doubt and negativity. One strategy that might be helpful is practicing mindfulness. Mindfulness involves paying attention to the present moment without judgment. You can start by taking deep breaths and bringing your awareness to your senses - what you see, hear, smell, taste, and touch. This practice can help redirect your thoughts away from negative self-talk and bring you back to the present moment.

While it's understandable that you're considering a diagnosis, it's important to remember that only a qualified mental health professional can provide an accurate assessment. However, if you feel that your symptoms are significantly impacting your daily life and functioning, it may be worth exploring further. They can provide you with a comprehensive evaluation and offer guidance on potential treatment options.

In the meantime, you can also try some self-help resources such as books or online articles that discuss anxiety, ADHD, and procrastination. These resources may provide additional insights and strategies that could be beneficial for you.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it's okay to take things one step at a time. You've already shown resilience by recognizing your struggles and seeking advice. Keep exploring different techniques and strategies until you find what works best for you.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i have these bad episode of anxiety that last for day where i m constantly dissociated and whenever i try to sleep i wake up almost every hour with my body completely numb and my vision is like zoomed out and everything is super disoriented and weird i m so tired but i can t sleep and it keep me up all night and i m so exhausted i just want at least one good night rest but i can t even get that i feel like anxiety and dissociation are constantly kicking me around and i can never catch a break in life

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how overwhelming and exhausting it can be to experience these episodes of anxiety and dissociation, especially when they interfere with your ability to sleep. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to help manage these symptoms.

One suggestion is to establish a consistent sleep routine. Going to bed and waking up at the same time every day, even on weekends, can help regulate your body's internal clock and improve the quality of your sleep. Additionally, creating a relaxing bedtime routine, such as reading a book or taking a warm bath, can signal to your body that it's time to wind down and prepare for sleep.

Another strategy you might find helpful is practicing relaxation techniques before bed. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or guided imagery can all help calm your mind and body, making it easier to fall asleep and stay asleep. You could also try incorporating these techniques into your daily routine, as they can help reduce overall anxiety levels throughout the day.

It's worth mentioning that while these suggestions may be beneficial for some individuals, they may not address the root causes of your anxiety and dissociation. If you feel that these symptoms are significantly impacting your daily life and well-being, it may be worth considering reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support. They can work with you to explore potential underlying factors contributing to your symptoms and develop a treatment plan tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, you deserve to have a good night's rest, and there are resources available to help you achieve that. Take care of yourself and don't hesitate to seek the help you need.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Additionally, it might be helpful to engage in activities or hobbies that bring you joy or a sense of purpose. This could be anything from painting, writing, exercising, or spending time in nature. Finding moments of happiness, no matter how small, can make a difference in your overall well-being.

[Question]
i have no idea if this is anxiety but this is the reason why im asking lately i ve been extremely overthinking the most smallest thing and worrying about the most thing that i ve been overthinking about this happens throughout the day and disrupts my life it s even disrupting me whilst i m typing i worry and overthink thing that could cause health problem but the thing are sooo small i ve wasted so many food thinking this could be dangerous i know it sound stupid because i can barely even explain it it s taking a toll on me but i know that the other day when i got outside the house i wasn t thinking about it and i felt better but then when i got back to the house and started up again i just know i keep overthinking and worrying about the smallest thing health related i can t tell you the amount of time that i ve been back and forth to the doctor this year and last year worrying myself

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how overwhelming it can be to constantly worry about the smallest things, especially when they seem to disrupt your daily life. It's important to remember that you're not alone in experiencing this, and there are steps you can take to manage your anxiety.

Firstly, it might be helpful to identify any patterns or triggers that contribute to your overthinking and worrying. Keeping a journal or making a list of the situations or thoughts that tend to trigger these feelings could provide some insight into what exactly is causing your anxiety.

Once you have identified these triggers, you can start implementing strategies to cope with them. One technique is called "thought stopping," where you mentally say "stop" when you catch yourself overthinking or worrying about something. This can help break the cycle of anxious thoughts.

Another approach is practicing mindfulness or meditation. These techniques can help you become more aware of your thoughts and emotions without judgment, allowing you to let go of some of the excessive worrying.

Additionally, engaging in regular physical activity, such as walking or yoga, can also be beneficial for managing anxiety. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters.

Lastly, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide guidance tailored specifically to your situation. They can offer additional coping mechanisms and support you on your journey towards managing your anxiety.

Remember, you deserve to live a life free from constant worry and overthinking. With time and effort, it is possible to find relief from these distressing thoughts.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

They can help you understand your anxiety better and develop coping strategies tailored to your specific needs.

In the meantime, there are some self-care practices you can try to manage your anxiety. Regular exercise, such as walking or yoga, can help reduce stress and promote relaxation. Additionally, practicing deep breathing exercises or mindfulness techniques can be beneficial in calming your mind and body.

It's also important to communicate openly with your girlfriend about your feelings and concerns. While it may be difficult, expressing your fears and worries to her can help create understanding and empathy between the two of you. You could let her know that you're working on managing your anxiety and that you value her support.

idk if anyone else get this i get anxiety poop sometimes but i also get anxiety vomit idk if it from excessive hyperventilating when i have an attack or just from the anxiety i get super nauseous and have no choice but to go vomit this can happen every night if it particularly bad doe anyone else get this i tried looking it up and i couldn t find much regarding vomiting when having a panic anxiety attack it the worst

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how distressing it can be to experience anxiety-related symptoms, especially when they involve physical sensations like vomiting. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this experience, and there are steps you can take to manage your anxiety and potentially reduce the frequency of these symptoms.

Firstly, it might be helpful to explore relaxation techniques that can help you calm your body and mind during an anxiety attack. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or guided imagery are some examples of techniques that could potentially reduce the intensity of your symptoms. You might find it beneficial to practice these techniques regularly, even when you're not experiencing an attack, to build up your resilience.

Additionally, it could be worth considering seeking support from a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and assistance. They can help you identify the underlying causes of your anxiety and develop a tailored treatment plan that may include therapy, medication, or other interventions.

In the meantime, you might want to keep a journal to track your symptoms and any patterns you notice. This can help you better understand your triggers and identify potential triggers that you can work on managing or avoiding.

Remember, everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so what works for one person may not work for another. It may take some trial and error to find the strategies that work best for you. Be patient with yourself as you navigate this process, and know that there is hope for finding relief from your symptoms.

i 9 f moved to a different state to support my partner while they re at school we went from a duel income household to me being the breadwinner i wa diagnosed with adhd anxiety and depression last year and am on med and in therapy i just keep screwing up at work the work isn t hard but i m making stupid mistake i feel like im not doing anything correctly i try to be thorough and am told by my bos that i m getting too caught up in the detail i try to be quick and cover the basic and am told that it isn t my best work i have no idea what to do i m told to ask question if i don t understand by my bos and when i do she s short with me example i asked if i should include document with a proposal because the last time i did there wa push back from someone saying they didn t need to provide the document she replied if i wa asking if i needed to follow to the standard operative procedure i feel stuck my performance ha been worse partially due to depression which ha affected my focus cue adhd issue med for that aren t working great i just feel so stuck i m literally cry once a week bc i feel like i m failing so badly i m literally doing working extra because i m behind and not charging for it bc i just feel like i m so behind i started this new job and wa immediately sent home to telework full time so i can t just ask the people around me for help

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how overwhelming and frustrating it can be to feel like you're not meeting expectations at work, especially when you're trying your best. It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of different challenges, including your diagnosis of ADHD, anxiety, and depression, as well as the added stress of being the sole breadwinner in your household and moving to a new state to support your partner.

Given all of these factors, it's not surprising that you're feeling stuck and struggling to find a balance between being thorough and being quick. It's important to remember that everyone makes mistakes and has moments of not meeting expectations, and it's okay to ask questions and clarify instructions when you're unsure.

One suggestion I have is to try breaking down your tasks into smaller, manageable steps. This can help you focus on one thing at a time and prevent getting too caught up in the details. Additionally, it might be helpful to discuss your concerns with your therapist about how your ADHD and anxiety are impacting your work performance. They can provide guidance tailored to your specific needs and help you explore coping strategies that work best for you.

Another suggestion is to consider reaching out to your supervisor or HR department for support. They may be able to provide accommodations or resources that can help you manage your workload more effectively. Additionally, it could be beneficial to explore any potential adjustments to your work schedule or remote work arrangements that may alleviate some of the stress and allow you to better balance your personal and professional responsibilities.

Remember, it's important to be kind to yourself and acknowledge that you're doing the best you can given your circumstances. It's okay to ask for help and support when needed, and there are resources available to assist you in managing your mental health and work-related challenges.

i ve had this ever since i wa young and now that i m in my adult year i feel like i m running out of time i m still at home and i feel stuck i can t hold down a job i ve lost over job let alone my therapist keep telling me to be compassionate towards myself but it s so hard i just want to be normal be happy my panic attack are bothering me lately more than ever and idk how to help it

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how difficult it can be to feel stuck and unfulfilled, especially when you've had these feelings for a long time. It's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and it's okay to take your time in finding what works best for you.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge the challenges you've faced in holding down a job and dealing with panic attacks. These are valid concerns that many people experience, and it's not uncommon to feel overwhelmed by them.

One suggestion I have is to explore different coping mechanisms for your panic attacks. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or even trying mindfulness techniques might help you manage your symptoms more effectively. Additionally, it could be beneficial to identify any triggers that seem to worsen your panic attacks and try to avoid them if possible.

Regarding your desire to be normal and happy, it's important to remember that these are subjective goals, and what "normal" or "happy" mean to you might differ from what others perceive as normal or happy. Instead of focusing on external measures of success, try to focus on personal growth and self-acceptance. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment, such as hobbies or creative outlets, can also contribute to your overall well-being.

Lastly, while it's understandable that you may feel frustrated with the lack of progress, it's crucial to be patient and kind to yourself throughout this process. Remember that change takes time, and setbacks are a normal part of growth. Consider reaching out to supportive friends or family members who can provide encouragement and understanding during this challenging period.

I hope these suggestions offer some guidance as you navigate your journey towards finding happiness and fulfillment. Remember, you deserve to live a life that brings you joy and peace, and I believe in your ability to achieve it.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i m not sure if this is the right subreddit to go to but i don t know where else to go my spouse ha struggled with severe depression his whole life it is genetic his dad wa the same any amount of pressure make him worse he constantly feel a though life is not worth living and he s a lost cause he will never feel okay and just want the pain to go away we have a baby coming any day now and i wa worried that pressure wa gon na send him over the edge we have been talking about having him voluntarily go to a psych ward and see if they can help kinda a a last ditch effort before i just give him permission to end it today he talked to his counselor about going to one in a few week after the baby wa here and they came and picked him up an hour later he is pissed doesn t want to be there which i understand is normal he feel completely betrayed by his councellor and never want to go back i m worried that now he is going to pretend like he is fine just to get out the point of this is to get help why won t he just take it i m scared the mental hospital won t help at all i just need you guy who have been there before to be honest with me did it help what thing helped and what made it worse if it doe help or when he come back home what are some thing i can do to continue the healing process or just make his life easier anything else you feel to share please do i hate not knowing thing and this is really killing me right now

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how difficult it is for you to navigate this situation. It's important to remember that your spouse's feelings and reactions are valid, even if they may not seem rational at times. The fact that he is resistant to going to the mental hospital does not necessarily mean that it won't help. It's common for individuals with depression to feel betrayed or resistant to professional help, but it doesn't mean that the help won't be beneficial in the long run.

In terms of what could help, it might be worth exploring different treatment options with your spouse's therapist or psychiatrist. They can provide guidance on medication, therapy techniques, or other interventions that could be effective for him. Additionally, you could encourage open communication between your spouse and his therapist, expressing your concerns and sharing your experiences as a caregiver. This might help your spouse feel more heard and understood.

When he comes back home, it's crucial to create a supportive environment for him. This means being patient, understanding, and non-judgmental. Encourage him to continue his therapy sessions and consider seeking out support groups or community resources that can provide additional assistance. Remember, healing takes time, and it's essential to focus on small steps forward rather than expecting immediate changes.

Lastly, take care of yourself as well. Dealing with a loved one's mental health challenges can be emotionally draining. Make sure to prioritize self-care activities such as exercise, hobbies, spending time with friends, or seeking therapy for yourself if needed.

Please keep in mind that I am not a mental health professional, but I hope these suggestions can provide some guidance and support during this challenging time.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

so i started having suicidal thought in april of last year and they lasted until around november in october i started hanging out with a girl and we started becoming good friend not romantic just friendship my mental health started getting a lot better after a couple month of friendship with her and it s kept getting better ever since a few day ago i made a passive aggressive comment that really upset her she won t text me back now i ve tried apologizing and trying to make thing right with her but i haven t heard back from her i m afraid i ve ruined this friendship forever and now my suicidal thought are back for the first time since last year i always hurt the people that i care about and i hate myself so much that i do this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you've been experiencing these thoughts and feelings. It takes a lot of courage to reach out for support, and I want you to know that you're not alone in this.

It's great to hear that you've been making progress with your mental health since October, and that your friendship with this girl has been a positive influence for you. However, it's understandable that making a passive aggressive comment may have caused some damage to your relationship with her.

When we hurt the people we care about, it's important to acknowledge our role in the situation and take responsibility for our actions. Apologizing and trying to make things right is a good first step, but it's also important to understand that healing relationships takes time and effort from both parties involved.

Regarding your suicidal thoughts, it's crucial that you reach out to someone you trust, such as a close friend, family member, or even a helpline. These thoughts can be overwhelming, but remember that there are people who care about you and want to help you through this.

Self-hatred is a common feeling when we hurt others, but it's important to remember that our actions don't define our worth as individuals. You deserve love and compassion, just like anyone else. Consider seeking therapy or counseling to explore these feelings and work towards building a healthier mindset.

Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and there are people who care about your well-being. Don't hesitate to reach out for support whenever you need it.

[Question]
so i have a mild stutter and i just had an epiphany i ve been letting my stutter control me but i found something amazing out i let my stutter define who i wa a a person instead of an aspect of myself it s so bad that when my parent talk to me like a normal person i d think to myself wow they act like i m normal despite my stutter they see past that and when i would work people would see my name tag and say oh i have a son named my name and i would think he probably doesn t stutter tho i let this define who i wa a a person and i let it really get to me i wa looking at old reddit post from other people asking how people view stutter and most people said they didn t care at all and even found it interesting some even said it wa hot cute made joke sound more natural and a a result more funny not like they found the stutter funny tho and one even said they were turned on by it and someone said something that stuck out to me they pretty much said how you perceive yourself is how others will so if i see myself a weird and anxious i will act that way and be perceived in that way but if i see myself a confident and charismatic and just act like my stutter doesn t bother me and even joke about it then others will perceive me a such this blew my mind a i thought everyone didn t pick up on my stutter at first and just thought i wa super weird but it s just me convincing myself of that so even tho this clicked i still can t just flick the switch off so how do i actually become confident with my stutter it s very mild and is fueled by anxiety so if i can get rid of my anxiety it ll in my opinion make me sound more charismatic and confident so i really wan na figure out how to just own it how do i do this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how difficult it can be to deal with a stutter and the impact it has on your self-perception and interactions with others. It's great that you've had this epiphany and recognized that you've been allowing your stutter to define who you are as a person.

To become more confident with your stutter, it might be helpful to start by challenging the negative thoughts and beliefs you have about yourself. When you catch yourself thinking that your stutter makes you weird or anxious, try to replace those thoughts with positive affirmations. Remind yourself that your stutter is just a part of you, and it doesn't define your worth as a person.

Another strategy you could try is gradually exposing yourself to situations where you can practice speaking confidently. Start small by practicing in front of a mirror or recording yourself. As you become more comfortable, you can gradually challenge yourself to speak in front of trusted friends or family members. Remember, it's okay to make mistakes and stumble over words. Nobody expects you to be perfect, and they will likely be understanding and supportive.

Additionally, consider seeking out support groups or online communities where you can connect with others who have similar experiences. Sharing your feelings and hearing from others who have overcome their own challenges can provide you with valuable insights and encouragement.

Lastly, if you find that your anxiety is significantly impacting your ability to be confident with your stutter, it may be beneficial to explore therapy options. A mental health professional can work with you to develop personalized strategies and techniques to manage your anxiety and build confidence in your communication skills.

Remember, progress takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate every small step forward. You have the potential to own your stutter and become the confident and charismatic person you aspire to be.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
so i ve struggled w executive dysfunction for 9 year throughout my year of college there wa not one assignment that i did not do the night before it wa due i studied late ate terribly amp went thru a terrible depression a year after graduating i still have a really hard time doing thing in general i stall before i do anything at all amp it oftentimes lead to me not doing the thing at all also i kind of live my entire life on pause only taking care of myself when i have something planned or to look forward to i left my job that i wa insanely good at bc the commitment amp longevity terrified me why can t i function amp what ha helped u work thru these feeling

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how challenging it can be to manage executive dysfunction and the emotional impact it has on your daily life. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this struggle, and there are steps you can take to improve your situation.

Firstly, it might be helpful to explore any underlying causes or triggers for your executive dysfunction. Are there specific stressors or situations that tend to exacerbate these symptoms? Identifying these triggers can help you develop coping strategies tailored to your needs.

Additionally, breaking tasks into smaller, manageable steps can make them feel less overwhelming. Prioritizing your responsibilities and setting realistic goals can also be beneficial. Consider using a planner or digital calendar to schedule your tasks and reminders, which can help you stay organized and focused.

Finding ways to incorporate structure and routine into your daily life can also be helpful. This could involve establishing a consistent sleep schedule, regular meal times, and dedicated time for self-care activities. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can also contribute to overall well-being.

While it's understandable that leaving your job was a difficult decision, it's important to remember that finding a new career path or job may not be the only solution. Exploring therapy options, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), could provide you with additional support and guidance in managing your executive dysfunction and associated emotions.

Remember, progress takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate even the smallest victories along the way.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

my memory s fading i m losing weight i don t sleep sex feel hollow i have no motivation to do anything and i frequently think about death i ve been seeing these symptom in myself on and off again for the past few year but never really put them together until now i attributed the weight loss to a study i read stating that just thinking about working out can have benefit despite not actually working out i never really thought of it a a symptom i just saw it a a positive slightly inexplicable development in my life i think i read that i have passive intrusive thought or something like that essentially i think about what it would be like if i wa dead but not about how i would want to die or anything like that the reason for it wa always lost on me i just learned to live with it my sleep issue motivation issue and lack of sexual pleasure have always been present so i never really thought twice about them i thought the memory loss wa due to my rare and infrequent use of recreational psychedelics when i connected all of these together i spent about 0 minute just trying to remember what i had for dinner last night which i found fairly upsetting a up until my teenage year i had an immaculate memory i d still consider myself happy at least to the extent that i ve always known but the symptom are there nevertheless and i m just finding the whole thing quite strange

Regarding your lack of motivation and hollow feeling, it could be beneficial to engage in activities that bring you joy or fulfillment. Surrounding yourself with supportive friends or family members who can provide encouragement and accountability can also be helpful.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It's important to acknowledge that your feelings of depression and stress are valid, and it's understandable that you're feeling a sense of hopelessness and self-hatred.

One suggestion I have is to try setting clear boundaries with your parents about your need for alone time. You could explain to them that you're going through a difficult time and need some space to process your emotions and regain your mental well-being. It might be helpful to involve a neutral third party, such as a trusted friend or family member, to help facilitate these conversations if you feel comfortable doing so.

Additionally, it could be beneficial to explore alternative ways to manage your stress and improve your sleep quality. This might include practicing relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing exercises or meditation, before bedtime to help calm your nervous system. You could also consider implementing a consistent sleep schedule, even if it means sacrificing some social activities temporarily.

Furthermore, it's crucial to remember that you're not alone in this struggle. While it may feel like there's no one to turn to, there are resources available that can provide support and guidance. You might consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can offer personalized strategies and therapy sessions tailored to your specific needs.

Lastly, please keep in mind that what you're going through is not your fault, and it's not uncommon for people to experience difficult times in their lives. You deserve compassion and understanding, and there is hope for healing and finding joy again.

i m a frequent poster here i ve struggled all my life with these feeling thing seemed like they were getting better i wa genuinely happy and then it got taken away again i live in shitty section housing i wa kicked out several year ago and i ve been struggling to stay afloat since my mother and i recently discussed me moving back home which wa le than ideal she bought a condo and offered it to me she even suggested i get a roommate i wa overjoyed my so could move in my best friend could move it it seemed wonderful and then once i already signed the paper to move out in two month my mother told me to stop looking for a roommate she ha been considering moving into the larger bedroom and taking my kid sister with her leaving me alone in the smaller bedroom with no support and i have no place to argue against this she bought me a new car a an early birthday gift she s paying for me to go through school i m currently struggling to keep my grade up and she s rightfully angry about it my apartment is messy and she s mad about that too rightfully so i am going to lose my privacy and be stuck in the tiny condo with her without support from my so and my best friend my mother is very controlling so i know i won t be able to play video game or talk to my friend in peace it ll just be lecturing do your homework look for a better job etc etc i don t have the motivation for either i barely have motivation to go to my current job she doesn t get that i m so incredibly depressed and suicidal every single fucking day i just got rejected for a better job and now on top of all that i ll be stuck in a confined space with her with no freedom again and i ll probably become babysitter again for the child i pretty much raised for her it s not fair

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how overwhelming and frustrating this situation must feel for you. It's important to acknowledge that you've been through a lot and it's understandable that you're feeling depressed and suicidal. Moving back home with your mother might not have been the ideal situation, but it seemed like a step towards independence and support. However, it seems that things have taken a turn for the worse.

Given your situation, it's crucial to prioritize your mental health and well-being. You mentioned that you're struggling to keep up with your school work and maintaining a clean living space. These are important aspects of self-care, and it's understandable that your mother is frustrated with the mess in your apartment. However, it's essential to find a balance between maintaining your privacy and meeting her expectations. You could discuss this with her and explore potential compromises, such as setting aside specific areas for your personal belongings and dedicating certain times for cleaning.

Regarding your lack of motivation, it's important to remember that depression can make it difficult to find the energy and drive to engage in activities, including your job and personal interests. It might be helpful to explore different coping mechanisms, such as setting small achievable goals, engaging in activities that bring you joy, or seeking support from a therapist or counselor who can provide guidance tailored to your specific needs.

Additionally, it's crucial to address your feelings of isolation and loneliness. While living with your mother may not provide the privacy and freedom you desire, it's essential to find ways to connect with others who understand and support you. This could involve reaching out to friends, joining social or support groups, or even considering online communities where you can share your experiences and find empathy.

Lastly, I want to emphasize the importance of reaching out for help if you're feeling suicidal. You don't have to face this alone, and there are resources available to support you. If you're in immediate danger, please contact emergency services or a helpline in your area.

Remember, you deserve to live a life that prioritizes your well-being and happiness. It may take time and effort, but with the right support and strategies, it's possible to find a balance that works for you.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

hi all i m f i ve had very bad anxiety disorder since 0 0 when my uncle passed away the following year i started taking medication and while it help it s not a cure all both my parent passed under different circumstance in october and it s wrecked my emotion i try to do the best i can but sometimes it s just a mess i m out of town right now and i feel so outside of my comfort zone i know i m safe but my stomach is in knot and sorry tmi i haven t left the bathroom much doe anyone have any advice is there anything i can do to calm myself or center myself thank you in advance

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how difficult it is to cope with the loss of loved ones and the anxiety that comes with it. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to help manage your anxiety.

First, it might be helpful to practice deep breathing exercises when you start feeling anxious. Take slow, deep breaths in through your nose, hold for a few seconds, and then exhale slowly through your mouth. This can help activate your body's relaxation response and calm your nervous system.

Additionally, you could try engaging in activities that bring you joy or provide a sense of calm. This could be anything from listening to music, going for a walk in nature, or practicing mindfulness meditation. These activities can help distract your mind from anxious thoughts and bring you back to the present moment.

It's also important to prioritize self-care during this time. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in regular physical activity. Taking care of your overall well-being can have a positive impact on your mental health.

Lastly, consider reaching out to a trusted friend or family member for support. Sometimes just talking about your feelings with someone who cares about you can provide comfort and perspective.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, so it may take some trial and error to find what works best for you. Be patient with yourself and know that it's okay to ask for help when you need it.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

heel on the floor but she wa nowhere to be found so i texted her and told her that i wa sorry for passing out from the alcohol but i meant every word i told her last night she didn t text me back till wa i disappointed hearing this yeah of course i wa but i texted her back saying that we can talk about this in person another time but for right now enjoy your weekend the next day we saw each other  I'm sorry to hear that you're going through such a difficult time. It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of challenges, from failing in college, to having a strained relationship with your family, and even losing the leadership role in an organization you were involved with. On top of all that, you've also experienced a complicated and confusing romantic situation with someone you cared about.

Given all of these challenges, it's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and uncertain about your future. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to help yourself through this difficult period.

Firstly, it might be helpful to focus on your academic situation. If you're struggling in college, consider reaching out to your professors or academic advisor to discuss your concerns. They may be able to provide guidance or suggest strategies to improve your grades. Additionally, exploring resources such as study groups or tutoring services could help you better understand the material and increase your chances of success.

Regarding your relationship with your family, it can be challenging to maintain a healthy connection when there are underlying issues. If you feel comfortable, you could try having an open and honest conversation with your parents about how you've been feeling. Expressing your concerns and feelings in a calm and respectful manner might help them understand your perspective and potentially lead to a more productive conversation.

As for the romantic situation, it's important to remember that relationships involve two people, and it's not always easy to predict how another person will react or feel. While it's understandable that you're hurt and disappointed, it might be beneficial to reflect on your own feelings and needs. Consider what you truly want from a relationship and whether this person aligns with those desires. Additionally, it could be helpful to focus on building a support system outside of this relationship. Surrounding yourself with friends, family, or even joining social groups or clubs that share your interests can provide you with a sense of community and companionship.

Lastly, if you're feeling overwhelmed and considering ending your life, please know that there is always hope for a brighter future. Reach out to a trusted friend, family member, or helpline for support. They can provide you with the guidance and assistance you need during this difficult time.

Remember, you have the strength and resilience to overcome these challenges. It may take time, but with the right support and resources, you can find your way forward and create a fulfilling life for yourself.

It's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and success looks different for everyone. You've been through a lot of trauma, and it's understandable that you're struggling with self-hatred and depression.

Additionally, it might be helpful to explore different coping mechanisms that could bring you some relief. For example, engaging in activities that you enjoy or find fulfilling, such as hobbies or creative outlets, could help distract you from negative thoughts and provide a sense of purpose.

You mentioned that you have a vacation booked, and I encourage you to take advantage of it when it comes. Use this time to disconnect from the daily routine and focus on self-care. Engage in activities that recharge you mentally, emotionally, and physically.

When you return from your vacation, it might be beneficial to establish a routine that aligns with your goals and values. This could involve setting small, achievable goals for yourself each day, such as completing one task or engaging in an activity that brings you joy. Celebrate these small victories along the way, as they can help boost your motivation and sense of accomplishment.

Lastly, if you find that your depression persists and interferes with your daily functioning, it could be worth considering reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide additional guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. They can help you explore deeper into your trauma and develop strategies to manage your depression more effectively.

Remember, change takes time and effort, but it is possible to find meaning and happiness in your life. Be patient with yourself as you navigate this journey, and know that you deserve to live a fulfilling and meaningful life.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling this way, and I want you to know that you're not alone. It takes a lot of strength to reach out and share your feelings with someone. I'm here to listen and provide support.

It's important to remember that you don't have to go through this alone. There are people who care about you and want to help.

You mentioned that you tell yourself to shut up when the suicidal ideation comes, and that's a really difficult thing to do. It's okay to acknowledge those feelings and let yourself feel them. Sometimes, just giving yourself permission to feel those emotions can be a big step towards healing.

You also mentioned that you tell yourself to live another day, and maybe you won't fuck it up. It's natural to want to hold onto hope, but it's important to remember that healing takes time. You've been through six attempts to kill yourself, and that's a lot to carry. It's okay to take things one step at a time and not put too much pressure on yourself.

You mentioned that deep down, you know that you're not wholly horrible. It's important to remember that everyone has their own struggles and challenges, and it doesn't define who they are as a person. You deserve to see the good in yourself and recognize your worth.

I encourage you to reach out to someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member, and let them know what you're going through. Sometimes, just talking about your feelings can help alleviate some of the burden you're carrying. Additionally, consider seeking professional help from a mental health therapist who can provide you with the guidance and support you need.

In situations like this, it can be helpful to prioritize your safety and well-being. Consider reaching out to a support system, such as a trusted friend or family member, who can provide a safe space for you to express your emotions and receive comfort. Additionally, practicing self-care activities, such as deep breathing exercises or engaging in hobbies that bring you joy, can help you manage your anxiety and promote relaxation.

It may also be beneficial to explore coping mechanisms specifically designed to address trauma, such as journaling, meditation, or therapy. [The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling this way, and I want you to know that you're not alone in your struggles. It takes a lot of courage to reach out and share your thoughts and feelings with someone. I understand that dealing with depression can be incredibly challenging, especially when resources and help seem scarce.

Firstly, I want to assure you that your feelings are valid, and it's important to acknowledge them. You're not worthless, and there is hope for a brighter future. While I'm not a mental health professional, I can offer some suggestions that might help you find the support you need.

One option could be to consider reaching out to helplines or crisis hotlines that are available 24/7. They can provide you with immediate assistance and connect you with local resources or professionals who can offer guidance tailored to your specific situation. You might also explore online communities or forums where individuals facing similar challenges can share their experiences and provide emotional support.

Additionally, it could be helpful to establish a support system in your small town. This could involve reaching out to trusted friends or family members who may be able to provide a listening ear or even accompany you to appointments or therapy sessions if necessary. Sometimes, simply having someone by your side can make a significant difference in your mental well-being.

Self-harm is a serious concern, and I encourage you to seek professional help as soon as possible. A mental health professional can work with you to develop coping strategies and explore any underlying issues contributing to your thoughts of self-harm. They can also provide you with a safety plan to ensure your safety during difficult moments.

Remember, you deserve to live a fulfilling life, and there are people who care about your well-being. It may take time and effort, but with the right support and resources, it is possible to overcome these challenges and find hope again.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

also i can t even look nobody in the eye because of it wtf do i do it s ruining the relationship i have with my family and parent it s just pissing me tf off i went to get a haircut today but walked tf out because i wa too anxious and my anxiety wa high so when i walked in i sat all the way in the back so my barber and other people wouldn t see me because of my dumbass anxiety but how else wa i gon na get a cut if he couldn t see me right so like i said i just walked tf out with my head down n cried when i got home

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how frustrating it can be to deal with anxiety, especially when it interferes with your daily life and relationships. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to manage your anxiety and improve your overall well-being.

First, it might be helpful to explore the root cause of your anxiety. Sometimes, underlying issues such as stress, trauma, or even certain medications can contribute to heightened anxiety levels. Consider keeping a journal to track your thoughts and feelings, which could provide valuable insights into what might be triggering your anxiety.

Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation can help calm your mind and body when anxiety arises. These techniques can be learned through online resources or even apps designed for stress reduction.

It's also important to consider seeking support from loved ones or joining a support group where you can connect with others who may be experiencing similar challenges. Sometimes, simply talking about your anxiety with someone who understands can provide a sense of relief and validation.

Lastly, if your anxiety continues to significantly impact your daily life and relationships, it may be beneficial to consult with a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support. They can work with you to develop coping strategies tailored to your specific needs and help you navigate through this difficult time.

Remember, managing anxiety takes time and effort, but with patience and persistence, you can find ways to alleviate your symptoms and improve your overall well-being.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

sorry if this is the wrong subreddit for a long time in my life all i wanted wa to have someone to be there for me a person that could love me back a much i love them back but now that i have it i don t know if it s what i wanted in my past i had suicidal friend that influenced a huge part of my life i begin to realize how stupid living wa and started to question why we live i m losing all my energy slowly and slowly i find myself losing all motivation and having no goal or dream anymore this reddit is my last ditch effort on seeking help from other people i ve already started to distance from everyone around me i know that i can t be the only one that s been or going through this how were you guy able to keep your energy and have a positive outlook on life

Reflecting on your past experiences, such as the influence of your suicidal friend, can provide insight into how these events may have affected you. Additionally, consider if there are any underlying factors contributing to your lack of motivation and loss of dreams.

Once you have a better understanding of what might be causing these feelings, you can start taking small steps towards regaining your energy and finding purpose in life. This could involve setting achievable goals for yourself, whether they're related to personal growth, hobbies, or even volunteering for a cause that resonates with you.

Finding support from others who may have gone through similar experiences could also be beneficial. Online communities or support groups focused on mental health can offer a safe space to connect with individuals who can relate to your struggles. Sharing your thoughts and feelings with them might help you feel less alone and provide you with new perspectives and coping strategies.

Remember, healing takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate any progress you make, no matter how small it may seem. You deserve to live a fulfilling and meaningful life, and with the right support and self-care, you can work towards achieving that.

i am year old and i finallly came to the conclusion that i need help with anxiety i signed up for therapy and will have my first session in a couple of day prior to the therapy session i met with a prescriber to discus medication they recomended starting me off on zoloft or lexapro in general i tend to think of medication a a last resort not just for thing like this but in all aspect for example i rarely used medinces perscribed to me for pain after surgery and would only use them if absolutely necesarry i don t even like taking ibuprofen for a headache unless it is unbearable given that i am trying to figure out whether or going on anxiety medication is necessary for me or not i am worried about going on something for the rest of my life and am a little concerned about the side effect on the other hand i have been reading some post on here about how much med helped people i am hoping to hear from some people that have been on any of these medication and what their experience were also if anyone ha any thought on whether or not someone that is new to this whole anexiety improvement journey should jump into med or just try therapy first and see how that go i always kind of ignored my anxiety and told myself that since i have been able to graduate from college with a good degree hold down a great job for several year and maintain good relationship that my anxiety must not be that bad but a time go by i am starting to feel like it is getting worse and is negatively impacting my happiness and is leading my to lean on stimulant and alcohol too much which doesn t seem like a long term healthy way of handling this i have also had a couple of concussion in the last few year so i am not sure how much that play into what i am going through i would really appreciate it if some people could speak to their experience or have any encouragement or advice for someone just starting out in therapy and potentially medication please reach out if i can add additional context to my situation to help clarity where i am at also i wa reading some other post on this sub about people being tired all of the time i have spent year trying to figure out medically why to no avail i am starting to wondering if my axiety is causing it can anyone speak to any experience or epiphany they have had with this thanks garrison

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand your concerns about starting on anxiety medication and the impact it could have on your life. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with medication is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another.

You mentioned that you've been able to manage your anxiety without medication in the past, but it seems like your symptoms have been worsening and impacting your overall well-being. In that case, it might be worth considering medication as an option. However, it's also important to explore therapy as a complementary approach to medication.

Therapy can provide you with tools and strategies to manage your anxiety in a healthier way. A therapist can help you identify triggers, develop coping mechanisms, and work towards long-term improvement. They can also support you in making informed decisions about whether or not to start medication.

Regarding your concerns about potential side effects, it's worth noting that many people find that medication helps them feel better without significant side effects. However, it's important to discuss these concerns with your therapist or prescriber so they can provide guidance and support tailored to your specific situation.

Additionally, it's great that you're seeking advice from others who have been through similar experiences. Hearing from individuals who have successfully managed their anxiety with a combination of therapy and medication can be helpful. Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another.

Lastly, regarding your fatigue, it's possible that your anxiety could be contributing to it. However, it's important to have a thorough medical evaluation to rule out any underlying medical conditions that might be causing your fatigue. Your therapist or primary care physician can help you explore this further.

I hope this guidance provides you with some clarity and encouragement as you embark on your anxi

i come from a pretty african evangelical household where mental health wasn t talked about or addressed growing up in the last few year i ve noticed intense wave of sadness and internal pain turn from short stint of time to practically everyday now there will be time period of elation but for the most part my disposition ha remained sad on an almost daily basis i feel anger irritability deep sadness about the way thing haven t worked out for me in the past or currently or intense rejection from others who may not intend their action to be rejection for example the housemate i live with are a married couple who i wa in their wedding so we re all friend when i first moved in they would always have dinner with me asking me what i wanted to eat for dinner but that ha tapered off and tonight i walked in from work late and saw they had dinner together and were enjoying tv it broke me and i went to my room feeling intense inner pain this stuff is so new to me i have no clue how to continue through life because nobody know i struggle with this i don t even know where to begin to share with others or begin to understand what help i need any advice would be much appreciated

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how difficult it is to navigate through these feelings, especially when they've been a part of your daily life for quite some time. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to begin understanding and addressing your emotions.

Firstly, it might be helpful to start by acknowledging and accepting your feelings. It's okay to feel sad, angry, or rejected, and it's okay to feel these emotions deeply. Try not to judge yourself for having these feelings, as they are a natural response to the experiences you've had.

Next, consider reaching out to someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member, and sharing what you've been going through. Opening up about your struggles can help alleviate some of the emotional burden you're carrying. Additionally, they may be able to offer support and guidance as you work through your emotions.

You could also explore different coping mechanisms that work for you. This might include engaging in activities that bring you joy or provide a sense of calm, such as listening to music, practicing mindfulness or meditation, journaling, or engaging in hobbies. Finding healthy outlets for your emotions can help you manage them in a constructive way.

It's also worth mentioning that seeking professional help from a mental health therapist could be beneficial for you. A therapist can provide a safe space for you to explore your emotions further, offer guidance tailored to your specific situation, and help you develop strategies to cope with your feelings effectively.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to take things one step at a time. Be patient with yourself as you navigate through this journey, and know that there is hope for a brighter future ahead.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i am so tired of having depression i hate how hard it is to get up and do the most basic thing day out of the week i don t even eat dinner because i can t get out of bed i m tired of having to put in the extra effort to hide it at work and in front of my family i ve been single for a year and a half after a year and a half long relationship but my social anxiety ha gotten so bad i can t even put myself out there i m so lonely but too afraid to make an attempt i don t think i could ever actually kill myself but i think about how much easier it would be if i wasn t alive a lot more than i used to

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how difficult it is to cope with depression and the impact it has on your daily life. It's important to remember that you're not alone in feeling this way, and there are steps you can take to improve your situation.

Firstly, it might be helpful to establish a routine for yourself. Start by setting small, achievable goals for each day, such as getting out of bed at a specific time or going for a short walk. Celebrate these accomplishments, no matter how small they may seem.

Regarding your social anxiety, consider gradually exposing yourself to social situations that make you uncomfortable. Start with smaller gatherings or activities where you feel more at ease, and gradually work your way up to larger events. Remember, everyone experiences some level of nervousness in social situations, so don't be too hard on yourself.

Additionally, finding a support system can make a significant difference. This could include joining a local community group or volunteering for a cause you care about. Connecting with others who share similar interests can help boost your confidence and provide a sense of belonging.

It's also crucial to prioritize self-care. Engage in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, whether it's reading, listening to music, practicing mindfulness, or engaging in hobbies. Taking care of your physical health through regular exercise, proper nutrition, and adequate sleep can also have a positive impact on your mental well-being.

Lastly, if you ever feel overwhelmed or have thoughts of self-harm, please reach out to a helpline or crisis hotline immediately. They are there to provide support and ensure your safety.

Remember, recovery takes time and effort, but with patience and perseverance, you can find ways to manage your depression and improve your overall well-being.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how frustrating and confusing it can be to experience these anxiety attacks, especially when they seem to be triggered by certain comments or situations. It's important to remember that you are not alone in feeling this way, and there are steps you can take to manage your anxiety and improve your overall well-being.

One approach you might find helpful is practicing deep breathing exercises. When you start feeling anxious, try taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. This can help calm your body's stress response and bring your heart rate back to a more normal level.

Another technique you could try is challenging negative thoughts. When you catch yourself thinking about potential hidden secrets or past experiences, ask yourself if there is any evidence to support these thoughts. Often, our minds create these thoughts without any basis in reality. By questioning their validity, you can begin to break free from their grip.

Additionally, it may be beneficial to explore any underlying emotions or traumas that could be contributing to your anxiety. Sometimes, past experiences or unresolved feelings can manifest as anxiety symptoms. Consider seeking support from a therapist who can help you navigate these emotions and develop coping strategies tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, managing anxiety takes time and practice, but with patience and persistence, you can learn to overcome these challenges and regain control over your emotions.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i have been on prozac since maybe september last year before prozac i wa on lexapro and i wa given the highest dose of that and it worked at first and then my anxiety started up really bad again out of nowhere so i wa switched to prozac and honestly i don t feel like i ve noticed a difference especially recently i ve been getting bad anxiety attack that have worsened the past couple month i haven t had attack this bad in month it s honestly the worst ha anyone else experienced this where it feel like nothing is helping your anxiety i just want to be better my mind feel like a mental prison also doe anyone have any tip or trick that have helped calm them during an anxiety attack

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how frustrating it can be when a medication that worked in the past stops being effective, and it's disheartening to experience such intense anxiety attacks. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with mental health is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. However, there are some general strategies that might help you during an anxiety attack:

1. Deep breathing exercises: When you feel an anxiety attack coming on, try taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. Focusing on your breath can help calm your nervous system and bring your attention back to the present moment.

2. Grounding techniques: Engaging your senses can help distract your mind from anxious thoughts. You could try focusing on the physical sensations of touch, such as rubbing your hands together or holding onto something solid. You could also listen to calming music or sounds, like nature sounds or gentle instrumental music.

3. Progressive muscle relaxation: This technique involves tensing and then releasing each muscle group in your body, starting from your toes and working your way up to your head. By consciously relaxing your muscles, you may be able to alleviate some of the physical tension associated with anxiety.

4. Challenge negative thoughts: Anxiety often feeds on negative thinking patterns. When you notice yourself having negative thoughts, try to challenge them by asking yourself if there is evidence to support those thoughts. Often, we find that our worries are not based on reality.

5. Self-care: Taking care of yourself physically and emotionally is crucial when dealing with anxiety. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. Additionally, consider talking to someone you trust about what you're going through, whether it's a friend, family member, or even a support group.

Remember, these are just general suggestions, and it's important to find what works best for you. If your anxiety continues to worsen or interfere with your daily life, it may be helpful to consult with a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

By bringing your attention to the present, you can begin to let go of some of those fears and worries. [Question]
i just can t seem to relax throughout the day every time i think about sitting down and reading watching a tv show meditating putting a face mask on etc i ve got 000 thing on my mind random stuff anxious thought thing i have to get done etcetc so i never get to truly relax i panic just thinking about reading cause it ll be calm and there s nothing to distract me from my thought until i m able to focus on the book which can take a while the only time i m able to actively relax is when i m tired after i ve worked out for h in the gym or late at night got ta find the sweet spot between anxious mess and falling asleep feel like walking a tightrope amp even when i manage to get there i have more important stuff to do than relaxing eg studying amp other stuff that my anxious self didn t manage to do

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how challenging it can be to find the time and mental space to truly relax amidst the demands of daily life. It's important to acknowledge that you're not alone in feeling this way, and there are steps you can take to help manage your anxiety and create a more relaxing routine.

One approach could be to start small and gradually build up your relaxation practice. Instead of trying to carve out an entire hour for reading or meditation right away, you might find it helpful to set aside just a few minutes each day for a calming activity. This could be as simple as taking a few deep breaths, listening to soothing music, or going for a short walk outside. By starting with small, manageable goals, you can gradually increase the amount of time you spend on relaxation techniques.

Additionally, it might be beneficial to explore different relaxation techniques that resonate with you. For example, if reading doesn't seem to be working, you could try guided meditation apps or podcasts, which can provide structured guidance and help redirect your focus away from anxious thoughts. Experimenting with different activities and finding what works best for you can make relaxation more enjoyable and effective.

Furthermore, it's essential to prioritize self-care and establish boundaries between work and leisure. While it's understandable that you have important tasks to complete, it's crucial not to neglect your mental well-being. Consider setting aside specific times during the day for relaxation and stick to those boundaries. Remember, taking care of yourself is not a luxury, but a necessity for maintaining overall health and productivity.

Lastly, if you find that your anxiety continues to interfere with your ability to relax, it may be beneficial to seek support from a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and strategies tailored to your specific needs. They can help you explore the underlying causes of your anxiety and develop coping mechanisms that work best for you.

Remember, finding the sweet spot between being anxious and falling asleep takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate even the smallest victories along the way.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]
